Graphical abstract The graphdiyne with single adsorbed alkali metal atoms (AM@GDY) complexes possess high-efficiency and high-selectivity for converting CO2 into HCOOH, and the limiting potentials are −0.56 V on Li@GDY and −0.16 V on Na@GDY monolayers. Carbon dioxide electrochemical reduction reaction (CO2RR) with proton-electron pair delineates an intriguing prospect for converting CO2 to useful chemicals. Here by means of first-principle computations, the geometric constructions, electronic structures, and CO2RR catalytic performance of graphdiyne with single adsorbed alkali metal atoms (AM@GDY) are systematically investigated. The calculated results validate that the AM@GDY complexes possess excellent stability. The catalytic performance is correlated with the size of alkali metal ions. The adsorption free energies of CO2 on AM@GDY surfaces show that the Li@GDY and Na@GDY can spontaneously capture CO2 molecules. The interactions between *OCHO specie and AM@GDY are stronger than that between *COOH and AM@GDY, which can promote the CO2 reduction to HCOOH. The AM@GDY complexes could efficiently convert CO2 into HCOOH with high-selectivity, and the limiting potentials are −0.56 V on Li@GDY and −0.16 V on Na@GDY monolayers. The present findings not only highlight the importance of AM@GDY for CO2 electroreduction but also indicate that they are potentially single-atom electrocatalysts. Keywords Graphdiyne Alkali metal Single-atom catalysts CO2 electroreduction First principles Introduction Growing emissions of carbon dioxide from energy-using and industrial activities has brought various problems to our only homeland [1,2]. The electrochemical conversion of CO2 into valuable chemicals and hydrocarbon-fuels by using clean, green and renewable energy is an attractive solution [3]. The electrochemical reduction reaction (CO2RR) process relies on energy efficiency and current density, which could minimize operating and capital costs [4,5]. However, the electrocatalysts are the key and essentials to CO2RR route, which could promote hydrogenation process via proton-electron transfers [6,7]. In the last few decades, CO2RR on a variety of transition metals (TM) has been systematically investigated [8,9]. However, the bottleneck problems of CO2RR are low efficiency, poor selectivity, and high limiting potential [10,11]. Besides, a few of metal-based electrocatalysts are costly, which would further increase the production cost [12,13]. Since Zhang et al. firstly synthesized the single Pt atom on FeOx in 2011 [14], various single-atom catalysts (SACs) have been designed [15–19]. The SACs exhibit excellent catalytic ability for various chemical reactions owing to 100 % atom utilization [20,21]. However, the appropriate templates are key to improve the catalytic activity of SACs [22], which could firmly anchor the highly reactive metal atom to enhance stability and prevent aggregation [23], At the same time, a variety of platforms have been designed to synthesis SACs, such as metal oxides [14,24], graphene [25,26], g-C3N4 [27], CN [28], C2N [29], transition-metal carbonitride (MXenes) [30], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [31] and covalent-organic frameworks (COFs) [32]. The two-dimension (2D) nano materials could provide more anchoring sites to capture the single atom due to the outstanding morphological features, which could be widely used as supports [33]. Here, we give a brief description for the various 2D based single-atom electrocatalysts toward CO2RR. Porous graphene is a significant substrate to anchor single metal atoms for SACs because of high chemical stability and specific surface area. Su et al. prepared Ni@N-doped graphene samples for CO2RR [34], which showed more excellent catalytic activity than Ni@graphene and N-doped graphene. Ni@N-doped graphene displays efficient faradaic efficiency of 90 % to produce CO. Karapinar et al. reported an inexpensive Cu-N-graphene composites for CO2 electroreduction [35]. They found that the atomically dispersed copper converted into metallic copper nanoparticles during the CO2RR electrolysis process, which eventually acts as catalytically active species. Jiao et al. conducted computation and experiment for Cu@g-C3N4 model toward CO2RR [27]. This sample exhibits good CO2RR activity and processes low limiting potential. Yang et al. designed 24 single metal atoms loaded in g-CN (TM@g-CN) [28]. The computational results showed that the adsorption free energies of *OH and *OCH species could be evaluated their catalytic performance. Their study predicted that the Ni@g-CN and Cu@g-CN complexes are the most promising SACs toward CO2RR. Abbasi et al. reported that Nb-doped MoS2 electrocatalyst display high current density for CO2 reduction into CO [36]. InSe is also used as a support for SACs. 2D InSe coordinated with single transition metal atoms (TM@InSe) were theoretically designed as SACs by Jiang et al. [37]. The calculation suggested that there is a linear scaling relationship among adsorption energies of CO2RR species for Rh, Mn, and Cu@InSe, not for Zn@InSe and Cr@InSe. The productions are different for different TM@InSe surfaces, which is CH4 on Cr@InSe (limiting potential (U L) of −0.36 V), HCOOH on Cu@InSe (U L = −0.11 V), and H2 on Rh@InSe (U L = −0.03 V). Graphdiyne (GDY) has been demonstrated to be a perfect platform for SACs [38]. The specific CCCC frameworks and sp-, sp 2-hybrid carbon can absorb metal atoms with high catalytic reactivity [39]. Many GDY based SACs, single Ni [40], Fe [40], Pt [41], Pd [42], and Mo [43] atoms anchoring on GDY have been synthesized. Their catalytic ability toward hydrogen-evolution reaction (HER) [40], oxygen-reduction reaction (ORR) [44], oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [45], and nitrogen-reduction reaction (NRR) [43] have been performed. Furthermore, density functional theory (DFT) computation showed that transition metals supported by GDY monolayer (TM@GDY) could be promising SACs for ORR [46], OER [47], HER [48], NRR [49], and CO2RR [50,51]. In 2018, Li et al. systematically investigated alkali metals (Li, Na, K)-adsorbed GDY (AM@GDY) to study their geometric configurations, stability, electronic, and nonlinear optical properties [52]. The AM atoms can greatly increase the first hyperpolarizability. Moreover, some investigations revealed that the well-dispersed main-metal elements (Mg, Al, and Ca) in the porous carbon exhibited efficient ability of CO2 capture and oxygen reduction [53,54]. Inspired by the above discussion, we investigate totally five alkali metal atoms supported on the GDY monolayer (AM@GDY) in this study. By employing DFT methods, the geometric structures, electronic properties, and CO2RR catalytic performance of AM@GDY are systematically investigated. Our findings further highlight the importance of AM@GDY for CO2 electroreduction. Computational details Spin-polarized electronic structure calculations were preformed by the Vienna ab initio simulation package code [55] with the projector-augmented wave approach and generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [56] with Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [57]. Semiempirical Grimme parameter DFT-D3 correction was taken to describe van der Waals corrections [58]. The cutoff energy of 500 eV was used. The 5 × 5×1 k-point meshes in Brillouin zone was sampled for structure optimization. While for electronic property, the k-point meshes was 11 × 11 × 1. The vacuum space was set as 20 Å. The cutoff maximal residual energy and force were 1 × 10−5 eV and 0.01 eV/Å, respectively. To find the minimum energy path (MEP), the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) approach was carried out with the spring constant between adjacent images of −5.0 eV Å−2 [59]. The transition state (TS) was confirmed by the frequency analysis. The activation barriers (E b) and reaction energies (ΔH) were calculated by E b = E TS − E IS and ΔH = E FS − E IS, where IS, TS, and FS are initial state, transition state, and final state, respectively. Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations were carried out by using the canonical (NVT) ensemble to evaluate the thermodynamic stability of AM@GDY complexes [60]. The binding energy or adsorption energies (E ads) between single AM atoms/ CO2RR species and catalysts was defined by (1) Eads  = Etot −Eadsorbate −Ecatalysts The cohesive energy (E coh) of bulk alkali metal (AM) was defined as (2) Ecoh  = EAM  − EAM,bulk where the E tot, E catalysts, E adsorbate, E AM and E AM, bulk are the total energies, energies of pristine GDY or catalysts, adsorbate, single AM atom, and a bulk AM atom, respectively. The Gibbs free energy differences (ΔG) was calculated by Δ G = Δ E + Δ Z E P + ∫ C P d T − T Δ S + Δ G p H + Δ G U , which was computed as the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) [61] model by using VASPsol code [62]. The dielectrics constant was set as 80 for H2O solvent to simulate electrolyte. In this equation, ΔE can be obtained via DFT total energies. ΔZPE, TΔS, and ∫ C P d T are zero-point energy correction, entropy correction, and enthalpic temperature correction at 298.15 K, respectively, which are calculated from the vibrational frequencies and NIST database [63]. ΔG U = eU, is the electrode potential contribution. ΔG pH = k B T × ln10 × pH = 0 for pH = 0 in acidic medium. The limiting potential (U L = −ΔG max /e) depends on the most positive free energy change (ΔG max). Results and discussion Model and stability The previous study shows that the lattice constant of 2 × 2 supercell GDY is 9.44 Å [64]. Then, the stability of GDY adsorption with a single alkali metal (AM@GDY) atom (AM = Li, Na, K, Rb, and Cs) was calculated by considering different adsorption sites (Fig. S1, ESI†). The optimized stable geometric structures of AM@GDY are shown in Fig. 1 a–e. We found two types of binding sites between AM and GDY. The Li atom is loaded at the corner of an 18C-ring (Fig. 1a) with the Li–C bond distance of 2.25/2.39 Å. Nevertheless, the captured Na, K, Rb, and Cs atoms are loaded in the central positions of 18-membered rings, and the bond distances of AMC are predicted to be 2.81, 3.04, 3.24, and 3.42 Å for Na@GDY, K@GDY, Rb@GDY, and Cs@GDY, respectively (Table 1 ). The cases of Li, Na, and K are consistent with a previous study of single alkali metal adsorbed graphdiyne clusters [52] and similar with AM ions complexes of crowns [65]. The bond distances of AMC are increased with increasing atomic radii of alkali metals. It should be noted that there is a height between the AM atoms and the GDY surfaces for K (h = 0.99 Å), Rb (h=1.49 Å), and Cs (h=1.86 Å) atoms. The calculated binding energies (E ads) of AM@GDY monolayers and cohesive energies of bulk AM atoms are depicted in Fig. 1f. The negative binding energies indicate that these AM atoms can anchor in the GDY surface spontaneously. The binding energies are more negative than the AM cohesive energy, which confirms these AM@GDY is more favorable to be SACs. To further evaluate the kinetic stability of AM@GDY, the MEP and migration energy barrier was calculated for these five AM single atoms diffusing between two neighbouring 18C-hexagons (Fig. 1h,i). As shown in Fig. 1g, the migration energy barriers are 0.75, 0.74, 0.62, 0.56, and 0.48 eV for Li, Na, K, Rb, and Cs single atoms, respectively, which agrees with the order of the atomic radius of AM atoms (Fig. S2, ESI†)). To get further insight into their geometric structures, we performed the Bader charge analysis [66] of AM@GDY systems. The electron localization function (ELF) and charge transfer are plotted in Fig. 1a–e and Table 1. The AM atoms lose 0.76−0.85 e, while the adjacent C atoms gain some electrons. These charge transfer can further promote structural stability. It should be noted that the AM lost electrons can capture the CO2 molecules and CO2RR species (*COOH, *OCHO) with negative charges. It can be seen that the AM atoms are energetically anchored in the 18C-hexagon in GDY to form SACs. Electronic property The electronic structures are important indicators to predict the catalytic performance [67]. To evaluate the electronic features of the AM@GDY complexes, the total density of states (TDOS) and projected DOS (PDOS) of AM and corresponding adjacent C atoms are shown in Fig. 2 a–e. The DOS of pristine GDY is depicted in Fig. 2a, the GDY is nonmagnetic and semiconductor with a small band gap of 0.47 eV, which agrees with the earlier report [64]. As depicted in Fig. 2b–f, these AM@GDY complexes exhibit similar DOS; the conduction bands gradually downward shift across the Fermi level. These AM@GDY complexes are different from that of the free GDY monolayer, which exhibit strong metallic character. The metallic character usually displays better charge transfer during the CO2RR. On the other hand, the strong hybridization can be seen between GDY and the AM atoms, which could indicate the highly structural stabilization of these AM@GDY systems. Adsorption of CO2 molecule The capture of CO2 molecules on AM@GDY surfaces is the first step during the CO2RR process. The free GDY monolayer has poor capacity for adsorption of CO2 molecules, and the calculated adsorption energy (E ads) is −0.15 eV. Then, the geometric structures of CO2 adsorption on these five AM@GDY surfaces were optimized by considering different adsorption sites and patterns. The optimized results and bond lengths of AMO and CO are illustrated in Fig. 3 . The CO2 is adsorbed to the AM atom in AM@GDY complexes with the end-on pattern. One can see that the bond distances of CO near the AM atoms are longer than the further ones (1.18 vs 1.17 Å). The bond lengths of AMO are 1.94, 2.37, 2.82, 3.01, and 3.24 Å for Li, Na, K, Rb, and Cs@GDY systems, respectively, due to different atomic radii of the AM atoms. The calculated adsorption energies of CO2 molecules [E ads(*CO2)] are shown in Table 2 . All the values of E ads(*CO2) are negative, which indicates that these AM@GDY complexes can adsorb CO2 molecules. To further study the adsorption behaviour of CO2 on AM@GDY complexes, the charge density difference (CDD) are calculated and depicted in Fig. 3. We can easily see that the charge is largely accumulated on the AMO bond and neighboring carbon atoms. Bader charge analysis (Table 2) shows that the AM atoms lose electrons, and the CO2 molecules gain electrons. For Li@GDY, the Li atom loses 1.72 e, and the E ads(*CO2) is −0.54 eV. Nevertheless, the Na, K, Rb, and Cs atoms lose fewer electrons (0.79−0.95 e), and the corresponding E ads(*CO2) decrease to −0.21 to −0.43 eV. These results illustrate that the adsorption capacity seriously depends on the variety of AM atoms. To gain further insight into the interaction between CO2 and AM@GDY complexes, the total density of states (TDOS) of CO2 adsorption on AM@GDY, PDOS of AM atoms, local DOS (LDOS) of adsorbed CO2, and LDOS of isolated CO2 were analyzed and compared in Fig. 4 . The adsorbed CO2 molecules do not change the spin density. These five adsorption systems exhibit nonmagnetic. The hybridization between AM atoms and CO2 can be seen from the PDOS and LDOS, which further confirms that the AM@GDY complexes can capture CO2 molecules. Besides, we plot the adsorption energies of CO2 [E ads(*CO2)] and distances between AM and CO2 in Fig. 4f, which clearly illustrates that the E ads(*CO2) is decreased with increasing the atomic radii of AM atoms. CO2 reduction reaction Firstly, the Gibbs adsorption free energies of CO2 [ΔG (*CO2)] are calculated via the reaction CO2+*→*CO2. As shown in Fig. 5 a, the Li@GDY and Na@GDY complexes have negative ΔG(*CO2), which indicates these two surfaces can spontaneously capture CO2. Thus, the K@GDY, Rb@GDY, and Cs@GDY monolayers are not considered in the following study owing to the positive ΔG(*CO2) of these AM@GDY complexes. Theoretical and experimental studies validated that HER is a major competing reaction for CO2RR in aqueous solution [68,69]. For HER, there is only one *H species. Its adsorption free energy [ΔG(*H)] can be usually employed to evaluate HER catalytic performance [70]. The optimized geometries of H adsorption on AM@GDY monolayers and corresponding bond distances of AMH (L H–AM) are illustrated in Fig. S3 (ESI†) and Table 2. The values of L H–AM are 2.28, 2.70, 3.24, 3.46, and 3.78 Å for Li, Na, K, Rb, and Cs@GDY systems, respectively, and these distances are longer than the corresponding values of D AM−CO2 (1.94, 2.37, 2.82, 3.01, and 3.24 Å). The computed adsorption free energies [ΔG(*H)] of *H are displayed in Fig. 5a. The largely positive ΔG(*H) suggests that the Li@GDY and Na@GDY complexes can be employed as SACs for CO2RR, not HER. The CO2RR catalytic performance of Li@GDY sheets is firstly diagnosed by calculating the free energy diagram. As presented in Fig. 5b, the first step for adsorption of CO2 is downhill by −0.12 eV (*+CO2 →*CO2). The second step for hydrogenation of *CO2 may form *COOH or *OCHO (*CO2 +H++e−→*COOH or *OCHO). The *OCHO species is more favorable than the formation of *COOH. Their uphill are 1.77 eV for *COOH and 0.56 eV for *OCHO. As shown in Fig. 5d, the bond distance of AMO in *OCHO is shorter than that for *COOH (1.70 vs 1.80 Å), which is responsible for the adsorption energies of *OCHO and *COOH species. The *OCHO further hydrogenation to generate *OCH2O has large uphill of 2.40 eV (*OCHO+H++e−→*OCH2O), while the generation of *HCOOH is exothermic by 0.40 eV (*OCHO+H++e−→*HCOOH). Thus, the formation of *HCOOH is energetically favorable. The *HCOOH can react to a H++e− to generate the *OCH (*HCOOH+H++e−→*OCH+H2O) or OCH2OH (*HCOOH+H++e−→*OCH2OH). However, these two paths are exothermic by 1.86 eV and 1.23 eV, respectively. Then the desorption of HCOOH is diagnosed, and the step can be open by adsorbing 0.09 eV heat energy. In accordance with the above discussion, the pathway for producing HCOOH is the most thermodynamically favourable process, and the limiting potential step is the first hydrogenation reaction (*CO2 +H++e−→*OCHO). The limiting potential is −0.56 V, which is a similar magnitude of energy barrier for h-BN/Cu (111) complex (U L= −0.57 V) [71] and Cu (211) surface (U L = −0.41 V) [72]. Then, the free energy pathway and geometric configurations of CO2RR species on Na@GDY surface are computed and depicted in Fig. 5c, d. Similar to Li@GDY sheet. The step of CO2 adsorption has a downhill in free energy of −0.01 eV. The formation of *OCHO is downhill by −0.09 eV, while the production of *COOH is uphill by 2.10 eV. The *COHO species could be further hydrogenated to form *HCOOH, the step should pass a small uphill of 0.16 eV. Then, the step of HCOOH desorption is uphill by 0.07 eV, which can be easily desorbed. Thus, the producing HCOOH is also favourable reaction pathway. However, the limiting potential step is the second hydrogenation reaction (*OCHO +H++e−→*HCOOH), and the limiting potential is −0.16 V. The limiting potential on Na@GDY is lower than that on Li@GDY surface, indicating that Na@GDY exhibits a higher catalytic performance for the conversion of CO2 selectively to HCOOH than that for Li@GDY monolayer. The small limiting potential for Na@GDY (U L = −0.16 V) surface is comparable to several CO2RR catalysts, such as In-doped SnP3 (U L= −0.17 V) [73], h-BN/ Ni (111) (U L= −0.10 V) [71], h-BN/Co(0001) (U L= −0.15 V) [71], and Cu@InSe (U L= −0.11 V) [37]. To further understand the electronic interaction between the adsorbates (*COOH and *OCHO) and AM@GDY catalysts, we calculated the DOS and the charge distribution of these intermediates absorbed on Li@GDY and Na@GDY catalysts in Fig. 6 . For Li@GDY surfaces, the main overlaps between Li and *OCHO (Fig. 6a) are more strong than that for Li and *COOH (Fig. 6b). The Bader charge computations show that the amount of charge transfer from Li@GDY to *OCHO is nearly two times as much as to the *COOH (0.78 vs 0.38 e). The DOS and charge analysis on Na@GDY are similar to on Li@GDY. The *OCHO and *COOH can gain 0.55 and 0.27 electrons when they are adsorbed on Na@GDY surface (Fig. 6c, d). These results explain the reason that the free energy barrier of *OCHO is relatively lower than that of *COOH, and further confirm their excellent catalytic performance toward CO2RR. Lastly, the structural stabilities of Li@GDY and Na@GDY SACs are further performed by the theoretical simulation of ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) at 300 K under 3 ps. As presented in Fig. 7 , the temperature and the corresponding total energy oscillate in a small area, the geometry frameworks are maintained well, suggesting that the single Li and Na atoms are firmly anchored on the hole. The Li@GDY and Na@GDY complexes are promising SACs for chemical reactions. Conclusions In conclusion, by using DFT computations, we have systematically investigated the geometric constructions, electronic structures, and CO2RR catalytic performance of five AM@GDY complexes. The alkali metal atoms are energetically preferentially adsorbed on the central positions of 18-membered rings. These AM@GDY monolayers possess excellent stability, which has been validated by AIMD and CI-NEB methods. These adsorption of alkali metal atoms on GDY can downward shift the conduction bands across the Fermi level, and these AM@GDY complexes exhibit strong metallic character. The adsorption behaviours of CO2 on AM@GDY are evaluated by adsorption energy, free adsorption energy, and DOS. The Li@GDY and Na@GDY can spontaneously capture CO2 molecules. The strong interaction between *OCHO species and AM@GDY can promote the CO2 reduction to HCOOH, which endows their superior catalytic character for CO2RR to HCOOH with rather low limiting potentials −0.56 V on Li@GDY and −0.16 V on Na@GDY. Consequently, it is seen that AM@GDY complexes may be considered as potential SACs for CO2 reduction electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: Carbon dioxide electrochemical reduction reaction (CO2RR) with proton-electron pair delineates an intriguing prospect for converting CO2 to useful chemicals. Here by means of first-principle computations, the geometric constructions, electronic structures, and CO2RR catalytic performance of graphdiyne with single adsorbed alkali metal atoms (AM@GDY) are systematically investigated. The calculated results validate that the AM@GDY complexes possess excellent stability. The catalytic performance is correlated with the size of alkali metal ions. The adsorption free energies of CO2 on AM@GDY surfaces show that the Li@GDY and Na@GDY can spontaneously capture CO2 molecules. The interactions between *OCHO specie and AM@GDY are stronger than that between *COOH and AM@GDY, which can promote the CO2 reduction to HCOOH. The AM@GDY complexes could efficiently convert CO2 into HCOOH with high-selectivity, and the limiting potentials are −0.56 V on Li@GDY and −0.16 V on Na@GDY monolayers. The present findings not only highlight the importance of AM@GDY for CO2 electroreduction but also indicate that they are potentially single-atom electrocatalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Atomic alkali metal anchoring on graphdiyne as single-atom catalysts for capture and conversion of CO2 to HCOOH
